docs.lead_paragraph: As part of Michelle Obama's healthy eating initiative, a group of major food retailers promised in 2011 to open or expand 1,500 grocery or convenience stores in and around neighborhoods with no supermarkets by 2016. By their own count, they're far short.

headline.main: Grocery Chains Leave Food Deserts Barren, AP Analysis Finds
headline.print_headline: Grocery Chains Leave Food Deserts Barren, AP Analysis Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: Tatiana Decrescenzo thought her dream had come true when she immigrated to the United States. But illnesses and low-paying jobs have forced her to take comfort in small gifts.

headline.main: Her Dream Fading, a Russian Immigrant Finds Solace in Singing
headline.print_headline: A Husband and Wife, Both Fighting Illness, Find Solace in Songs

docs.abstract: Shorefront YM-YWHA of Brighton-Manhattan Beach, beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, helps Zoryan Fedchishin buy electric scooter to transport him to doctor.
docs.snippet: Tatiana Decrescenzo thought her dream had come true when she immigrated to the United States. But illnesses and low-paying jobs have forced her to take comfort in small gifts.

docs.lead_paragraph: A widening U.S. E. coli outbreak has slammed sales at Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc, the company said on Friday, hours after federal authorities reported that people in nine states have now contracted food poisoning.

headline.main: Chipotle Sales Battered by Widening E. Coli Outbreak
headline.print_headline: Chipotle Sales Battered by Widening E. Coli Outbreak

docs.snippet: A widening U.S. E. coli outbreak has slammed sales at Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc, the company said on Friday, hours after federal authorities reported that people in nine states have now contracted food poisoning.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma woman was arrested for suspected child abuse after doctors treating her 5-year-old daughter over the weekend reported that the child weighed 19 pounds and was severely malnourished, police said on Thursday.

headline.main: Oklahoma Mother Arrested for Starving Five-Year-Old Daughter
headline.print_headline: Oklahoma Mother Arrested for Starving Five-Year-Old Daughter

docs.snippet: An Oklahoma woman was arrested for suspected child abuse after doctors treating her 5-year-old daughter over the weekend reported that the child weighed 19 pounds and was severely malnourished, police said on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Grocery Manufacturers Association says the code, with information on ingredients and nutrition, will appear on about 30,000 products by the end of 2017.

headline.main: Food Companies to Add Scan Codes With More Product Details
headline.print_headline: Food Company Scan Codes to Add More Product Details

docs.abstract: About 30 food companies unveil plans to add scannable codes called Smart Label to their packaging; customers can use codes with their smartphones to get information about ingredients, allergens and nutrition.
docs.snippet: The Grocery Manufacturers Association says the code, with information on ingredients and nutrition, will appear on about 30,000 products by the end of 2017.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ending hunger by 2030, one of 17 global goals adopted in September, can only happen if more money and effort are invested in helping people cope with climate change impacts, the head of the U.N.'s food aid agency said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A family's attorney is alleging that money is behind a Reno hospital's rush to pull the life-support plug from a 20-year-old woman declared brain dead by doctors more than six months ago.

headline.main: Nevada Judge Sets More Hearings in Reno End-Of-Life Case
headline.print_headline: Nevada Judge Sets More Hearings in Reno End-Of-Life Case

docs.lead_paragraph: A current employee of the Human Resources Administration, along with one who had been fired and 11 others, were charged with wire fraud and conspiracy to commit mail fraud.

headline.main: Two New York City Workers Charged With Stealing $2.1 Million From Benefits Programs
headline.print_headline: 2 City Workers Charged With Stealing $2.1 Million From Benefits Programs

docs.abstract: New York City Human Resources Administration employee Cherrise Watson-Jackson and former employee Petronila Peralta are arrested and charged with stealing $2.1 million from number of government benefit programs; eleven others are also charged in case, which authorities describe as elaborate fraud scheme; separately, city's Dept of Investigation releases report identifying past fraud schemes perpetrated by other administration employees.
docs.snippet: A current employee of the Human Resources Administration, along with one who had been fired and 11 others, were charged with wire fraud and conspiracy to commit mail fraud.
